awd_titl_txt: Geometry, Algebra, and Topology of Face Numbers
awd_abstract_narration:
From antiquity, people looked at and studied objects such as polygons, pyramids, cubes, and their higher-dimensional generalizations called polytopes. Using these objects as building blocks and gluing them face-to-face, one may construct more involved objects known as polytopal complexes. For instance, any object obtained by gluing triangles, pyramids, and their higher-dimensional analogs is known as a simplicial complex, while an object obtained by gluing cubes of various dimensions is known as a cubical complex. The reason to study polytopes and polytopal complexes is explained by the fact that many continuous objects can be approximated by these more discrete structures. These objects also often show up in problems related to optimization, statistics, and engineering. For instance, the space of motions of a robot sometimes can be described by a cubical or simplicial complex. Simplicial complexes are also useful in describing patterns of intersections of convex sets, which, in turn, has applications in such subjects as neuro-biology (e.g., in the study of neurons which are simultaneously active in response to some stimulus). This research project aims to deepen understanding of various aspects of simplicial complexes. The award provides support of research training of graduate students.

The research project aims to attack several fundamental questions related to (1) studying the face numbers of centrally symmetric simplicial polytopes and spheres (2) extending the results on the face numbers and Stanley--Reisner rings of triangulations of manifolds to the setting of pseudomanifolds, and (3) exploring the effect of various topological invariants (beyond the usual Betti numbers) on the face numbers of manifolds and pseudomanifolds. For instance, while (as of a few months ago), the upper bound problem for centrally symmetric simplicial spheres is now completely resolved, there is not even a plausible upper bound conjecture for centrally symmetric polytopes; while we understand reasonably well the face-vectors of simplicial manifolds with and without boundary, very little is known about face-vectors of triangulations of spaces with singularities. While Betti numbers play a prominent role in the study of face-vectors, our knowledge on how other topological invariants (e.g., the fundamental group, characteristic classes, etc.) affect the face-vectors is next to nothing. The aim of this project is to attack these and related problems and in the process develop the necessary new combinatorial, geometric, and algebraic tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this proposal was to attack several fundamental problems related to combinatorics, algebra, and geometry of polytopes and simplicial complexes.

Polytopes are higher-dimensional analogs of polygons and objects such as pyramids, cubes, and octahedra, to name just a few. Algebraically, polytopes can be described as solution sets to systems of linear equations and linear inequalities in many variables. For instance, a point, a line segment, a triangle, a tetrahedron, as well as their higher-dimensional analogs are examples of polytopes called simplices. Polytopes have flat sides, known as faces; for example, a 3-dimensional cube has eight vertices (or 0-faces), twelve edges (or 1-faces), and six 2-faces. A polytope is called simplicial if all its faces are simplices.

A simplicial complex is an object obtained by gluing simplices together so that every two of them intersect along a common (possibly empty) face. A simplicial complex (or more precisely, the collection of vertex sets of its simplices) provides a combinatorial way to represent a topological space. We say that a simplicial complex is a simplicial sphere if it represents a space homeomorphic to a sphere.

While polytopes and simplicial complexes are extensively studied objects that have applications in and connections to discrete geometry, optimization, algebra, and topology, among others, many problems and conjectures in the field remain open and known to be notoriously difficult.

The PI, in collaboration with Hailun Zheng, succeeded in solving several such conjectures. Below is the summary of some of their results.

One of the major problems in the field is the lack of construction techniques. Zheng and the PI constructed several new families of simplicial spheres that are extremal with respect to certain properties. Specifically, they constructed new families of highly neighborly simplicial spheres as well as highly neighborly centrally symmetric spheres. (These objects are important because of their connection to the Upper Bound Theorems.) They also showed that some of these simplicial spheres have higher transversal ratios than the previous record.

Zheng and the PI constructed new families of (d-j)-simplicial j-simple d-dimensional polytopes. Being (d-j)-simplicial means that every face of dimension d-j is a simplex and hence has d-j+1 vertices; being j-simple is a dual property: every (d-j-1)-face is contained in exactly j+1 facets (i.e., faces of the highest dimension). The question of whether (d-j)-simplicial j-simple d-dimensional polytopes exist was raised in the mid-1960s, and the constructions presented by Zheng and the PI substantially advance our state of knowledge on the problem.

The PI in collaboration with Zheng, and more recently, with Murai and Zheng, resolved some of the reconstruction conjectures posed by Gil Kalai. The question here is what partial information about a simplicial polytope (or a simplicial sphere) allows us to determine the entire facial structure of this object. More ambitiously, what partial information allows us to determine the position vectors of all the vertices (up to affine equivalence)? The conjectural answers involved spaces of (higher) affine stresses. To prove these conjectures, the PI and her collaborators developed new interpretations of the spaces of stresses. Since affine stresses (along with the Stanley-Reisner rings) play an essential role in the theory of face numbers, the PI hopes that this work will have impact on other problems in the field.

The PI also wrote a survey paper Face numbers: the upper bound side of the story for the Proceedings of the 2022 International Congress of Mathematics.

Over the period of this grant, the PI has graduated three PhD students and mentored one postdoc. She is currently advising three PhD students. The PI serves on the editorial boards of the Proceedings of the American Math Society, SIAM Journal on Discrete Mathematics, and Algebraic Combinatorics. In the last two years, the PI has co-organized two international conferences. She also co-organizes the Combinatorics seminar at the University of Washington.
